marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Collection consists of the will of General Cadwalader, and a bill for taxes due from the estate.
Resident of South Londonderry (Windham Co.), Vermont.
Principally letters of private Henry L. Campbell, 2nd Regiment, U.S. Sharpshooters, to his mother Anna, concerning his activities.
Collection contains Callaway's bills and receipts.
U.S. Congressman and chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Collection contains a letter from Joel Roberts Poinsett to Cambreleng concerning financial matters. A second letter is from William C. Rives and discusses the French Claims Controversy as expressed in Andrew Jackson's annual message to Congress.
Collection contains business, personal, and legal papers of Judge Camden, including a letter of 1887 describing the Loomis National Library Association.
Collection contains family letters to Calhoun, including references to horse-powered cotton gins in La., 1847, and farm prices, 1851.

Letters from prominent N.C. officials and friends of Caldwell, concerning North Carolina politics, internal affairs, and family matters. One letter of 1864 reports on the trials of deserters and the shortage of rations. Another letter of 1848 mentions the Whigs and the recent presidential election.
A letter from W. S. Slaughter; a biographical sketch of Robert Cammack, farmer, and a soldier in the War of 1812, and father of C. W. Cammack; and an obituary of Robert Cammack.

Collection contains letters to Caldwell concerning propective students. There are some letters from the Gaddy family in Arkansas and an itinerant minister. Topics include crops, economic conditions, railroad construction, religious activities, and frontier conditions.

Personal letters from family and friends in Mississippi. Several letters during the Civil War describe prison conditions at Johnson's Island, Ohio. Letters in 1866 discuss social and economic conditions in Mississippi, and continuing secessionist influence as well as the possibility of renewed conflict with Union sympathizers.
Olin (Iredell Co.), and Clarksville (Dare Co.), N.C. resident.
Collection contains personal letters from Confederate soldiers in camps in Va. and N.C., and from schoolmates.
Collection contains personal letters of Camden, probably a Confederate soldier.
Resident of South Brookfield (Madison Co.), N.Y.

Letters to Kate Camenga from a soldier in the 7th New York Battery, 10th Corps, U.S.A., concerning military activities around Richmond, 1864-1865, and from Diedrich F. Camenga at the U.S. Army General Hospital at Point Lookout, Md., describing the food, Afro-American soldiers, weather, nuns serving as nurses, and the search for John Wilkes Booth.

Describes campaigns at Chancellorsville, Gettysburg, and Rappahannock Station, as well as various picket actions and skirmishes. Discusses camp life, casualties, deserters, discipline, foraging, and prisoners, and mentions U.S. generals Joseph J. Bartlett, George G. Meade, John Sedgwick, and Horatio G. Wright.
Collection consists of petitions, concerning the revocation of Caldwell's business license by officials of the Federal Army.

Two letters from Timothy Murphy concerning family matters, crops, the building of a road, and the Freehold Railroad; a letter from John Coffing pertaining to a lawsuit against the Housatonic Railroad; and a tax notice.

Collection contains letters from John McIntosh Kell, adjutant general of Georgia, and letters from Stephen D. Lee concerning the Confederate Veterans Association and the Confederate Soldiers' Home at Atlanta.
Public official and lieutenant colonel of the Fourth Battalion, Ga. Volunteers.
Collection contains a list of birds observed in western N.C. by Cairns.
Attorney and nephew of John C. Calhoun.

Collection contains letters chiefly concerning the controversy over whether or not the last Confederate Cabinet meeting was held in South Carolina or Georgia. Principal political figures are discussed. There is also a letter of 1912 pertaining to the gubernatorial election in S.C.

Letters to Calvert as editor of the Entomological News, concerning articles for that journal, editorial policy, nomenclature in entomology, rules and suggestions for contributions to the journal, and the character of Fordyce Grinnell, Jr.
California Perfume Company color plate catalog,

Color plate catalog (100 p., 18 x 26 cm) of perfumes, toilet waters, powders, cosmetics, creams, bath salts, hair products, dental products, and household specialties. Gift packages and sets for both women and men are offered. There is a page holding samples of face powder, rouge, and lipstick shades. Also contains an advertisement for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition, where the company won a gold medal. Bound in soft blue artificial leather fastened with posts. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.
This copy has suffered some water damage on the first thirty pages.
John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.
Collection contains family correspondence of Cadman, describing life at Great Lakes Naval Station, his transfer to Philadelphia, and opinion on the duration of the war.
Great Lakes Naval Training Center (Great Lakes, Ill.)
